newsitem.title: USA: INTERVIEW - Microsoft nears Office release.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Microsoft nears Office release.

text.p: Microsoft Corp's Office 97 productivity suite upgrade will be available in retail stores nationwide January 23, a company executive said.

Dennis Tevlin, group product manager, said in an interview that the product is on schedule. It will be released to manufacturing and to the company's "Select" license customers sometime in the fourth quarter, although he declined to be specific.
He called the upgrade "the most significant release we've had to date" of the product, which has more than 80 percent of the market for such suites.
Some industry analysts had expected Office 97 to be available in the retail channel in the fourth quarter.

But two analysts contacted by Reuters said the slight delay would not affect Microsoft's fiscal second-quarter earnings because the company plans to defer recognizing much of the Office revenue, anyway.
Tevlin took issue with a Dataquest study released earlier that showed signs of a slowdown in the worldwide suite market and a decline in Microsoft's share of it.
Microsoft stock fell 3-5/8 to 132 on nearly 5.8 million shares traded, although analysts were not sure whether the Dataquest study was a cause.
"Our business is not waning at all," Tevlin said. "Our market share seems to be relatively stable. Our business is doing great."
He said the Dataquest figures concentrated on "sell-in" to retailers, rather than "sell-through" to customers.
He also said the Dataquest figures inflated International Business Machines Corp's market share because the company is bundling its SmartSuite software with its Aptiva personal computers.
Tevlin said many IBM customers use Microsoft's Office suite, anyway.

And he said when sales of word-processor software are added in, Corel Corp's revenues and volume is down compared with figures from a year-earlier, when WordPerfect and what then was known as the Perfect Office suite were owned by Novell Inc.
